ffects of foliar applications of zinc and boron nano-fertilizers on omegranate (Punica granatum cv. Ardestani) fruit yield and quality
ohrab Davarpanah a, Ali Tehranifar a,∗, Gholamhossein Davarynejad a, Javier Abadía b, eza Khorasani c
Department of Horticultural Science and Landscape, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Iran Department of Plant Nutrition, Estación Experimental de Aula Dei (CSIC), Zaragoza, Spain Department of Soil Science, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Iran

a b s t r a c t
This study was carried out to assess the effects of the foliar application of nano-fertilizers of zinc (Zn) and boron (B) on pomegranate (Punica granatum cv. Ardestani) fruit yield and quality. A factorial experiment was conducted based on a completely randomized block design, with nine treatments and four replications per treatment. Foliar sprays of nano-Zn chelate fertiliser at three concentrations (0, 60 and 120 mg Zn L−1) and nano-B chelate fertiliser (0, 3.25 and 6.5 mg B L−1) were applied as a single spray before full bloom at a rate of 5.3 L tree−1. The application of Zn and B increased the leaf concentrations of both microelements in August, reflecting the improvements in tree nutrient status. A single foliar spray with relatively low amounts of B or Zn nano-fertilizers (34 mg B tree−1 or 636 mg Zn tree−1, respectively) led to increases in pomegranate fruit yield, and this was mainly due to increases in the number of fruits per tree. The effect was not as large with Zn as with B. Fertilization with the highest of the two doses led to significant improvements in fruit quality, including 4.4–7.6% increases in TSS, 9.5–29.1% decreases in TA, 20.6–46.1% increases in maturity index and 0.28–0.62 pH unit increases in juice pH, whereas physical fruit characteristics were unaffected. Changes in total sugars and total phenolic compounds were only minor, whereas the antioxidant activity and total anthocyanins were unaffected.

. Introduction
Pomegranate (Punica granatum L.) is a fruit tree of the Punicaceae amily, which is mainly grown in subtropical and tropical regions Adsule and Patil, 1995; Naik and Chand, 2011). Pomegranate fruits re consumed fresh or processed, and they are considered as a ealthy food because of the high content of antioxidant compounds Legua et al., 2012). In Iran, approximately 75% of pomegranate ruits are produced in five provinces, Fars, Khorasan, Markazi, Isfaan and Yazd (Varasteh et al., 2009), and pomegranate is consumed resh as well as in processed forms for jams, jellies, syrups and juices Kays, 1999; Alighourchi et al., 2008). Pomegranate is one of the
ost important commercial fruits in Iran: in 2015 the total area for omegranate cultivation was 81,700 ha, and the total production
as ca. 990,000 t (Anonymous, 2015).
Addition of fertilizers to supplement the natural soil fertility s essential for modern crop production, and precise manage-
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: tehranifar@um.ac.ir (A. Tehranifar).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scienta.2016.07.003 304-4238/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
ment of nutrient elements is essential for a sustainable agriculture production (Barker and Pilbeam, 2006). In particular, microelements have important roles in fruit set and retention, as well as in fruit yield and quality (Singh and Ram, 1983; Khan et al., 1993). Zinc (Zn) is one of the essential micronutrients for plants, and Zn deficiency is common in many crops (Swietlik, 1999; Marschner, 2012; Ojeda-Barrios et al., 2014). Zinc is required for the activity of different enzymes, including dehydrogenases, aldolases, isomerases, transphosphorylases, RNA and DNA polymerases, and is also involved in the synthesis of tryptophan, cell division, maintenance of membrane structure and photosynthesis, and acts as a regulatory cofactor in protein synthesis (Marschner, 2012). Boron (B) deficiency is also a common micronutrient problem in agriculture, which results in yield reductions and impaired crop quality (Barker and Pilbeam, 2006). Boron roles in plants include effects on the germination of pollen grains, the elongation of pollen tube, fruit set and yield, and is also indirectly responsible for the activation of dehydrogenase enzymes, sugar translocation, nucleic acids and plant hormones (Brady and Weil, 1996; El-Sheikh et al., 2007; Marschner, 2012).

Foliar sprays with fertilizers including microelements such as n, B, copper (Cu), manganese (Mn) and iron (Fe) have been shown o be convenient for field use, have a good effectiveness and very apid plant response (Fernández et al., 2013). Also, foliar fertilizers elp to avoid toxicity symptoms that may occur after soil appliation of the same microelements (Obreza et al., 2010). On the ther hand, many problems in different fields of science and indusry have been solved using nano-technologies (Scott and Chen, 003), which are currently used for production, processing and pplication of nano-scale complexes. Materials that are smaller han 100 nm, at least in one dimension, are generally classified s nano-materials. Applications of this new technology have been ound in agriculture, and nano-technologies are already applied to roduction, processing, storage, packing and transportation of agriultural products (Scott and Chen, 2003; Wiesner et al., 2006). The ost important application of nanotechnology in agricultural crop roduction is the field of nano-fertilizers, which can feed plants radually in a controlled manner, conversely to what occurs in the ase of common fertilizers. These nano-fertilizers can be more effiient, decreasing soil pollution and other environmental risks that ay occur when using chemical fertilizers (Naderi et al., 2011). ne of the advantages of using nano-fertilizers is that application an be done in smaller amounts than when using common fertilzers (Selivanov and Zorin, 2001; Reynolds, 2002; Raikova et al., 006; Batsmanova et al., 2013; Subramanian et al., 2015). Nanoaterials can be used for designing new Zn fertilizers, with the olubility, diffusion and availability of Zn to plants being affected by he nano-particulate Zn characteristics (size, specific surface area nd reactivity) (Subramanian and Sharmila Rahale, 2012; Mosanna nd Khalilvand, 2015). For instance, positive effects of the appliation of nano-ZnO were reported on seed germination, seedling igour, leaf chlorophyll content, stem and root growth in peanut Prasad et al., 2012), and the positive effects of nano-ZnO contrasted ith the negative effects on vegetable seed germination of a bulk orm of ZnO (Singh et al., 2013). The aim of this study was to test the effects of nano-Zn and ano-B fertilizers on the tree mineral nutrition status and fruit yield nd quality in pomegranate trees grown in an important agriculural area in North Eastern Iran. In this area soils are sandy and ith high pH, and therefore they are poor in nutrients. To the best f our knowledge, no studies have been conducted to investigate he effect of nano-Zn and nano-B fertilizers on pomegranate trees o far. The pomegranate cv. used, ‘Ardestani’, is of Iranian origin, ate ripening and with rounded shape, red skin and aril, and of the weet-sour type, and it is mostly used for fresh consumption.
. Materials and methods
.1. Experimental site, plant materials and treatments
The experiment was carried out in two seasons, 2014 and 2015, n a commercial pomegranate (Punica granatum L., cv. ‘Ardestani’) rchard. The orchard was located in the central part of the Razavi horasan province in North Eastern Iran (Tous Dasht; lat. 35◦1′ 4.33′′N, long. 58◦50′19.61′′E, altitude 967 m). The soil was a coarseoamy over fragmental, mixed, thermic xeric Torriorthents (64% and, 12% clay and 24% silt), with a pH of 8.08 in water and an EC f 9.4 dS m−1. The region is arid, with 248 mm of annual mean preipitation and a mean annual temperature of 14.8 ◦C. Trees were ight-year-old, with three trunks and approximately 2.5–3 m in eight. Trees were planted in regular rows, with a 3 × 5 m frame 667 trees ha−1), irrigated by a drip irrigation system and treated n winter with NPK fertilizers at 150:150:150 g tree−1. A factorial xperiment was carried out based on completely randomized block esign with nine fertilisation treatments and four replications per
rticulturae 210 (2016) 1–8
treatment. The two products used were “Nano Zinc Chelate Fertiliser” (120 g Zn L−1) and “Nano chelated fertiliser Boron” (6.5 g B L−1) (Sepher Parmis, Teheran, Iran), and both contain nanoparticles (composition patent-protected, average size 50 nm, range from 23 to 80 nm; ). Fertilizers were used in combined spray applications at concentrations 0, 60 and 120 mg Zn L−1 (Zn0, Zn1, and Zn2, respectively; equivalent to 0.0, 0.9 and 1.8 mM Zn) and 0, 3.25 and 6.5 mg B L−1 (B0, B1, and B2, respectively; equivalent to 0.0, 0.3 and 0.6 mM B). The nine treatments were named Zn0 + B0 (control), Zn1 + B0, Zn2 + B0, Zn0 + B1, Zn1 + B1, Zn2 + B1, Zn0 + B2, Zn1 + B2 and Zn2 + B2. The fertiliser solution was prepared by diluting the commercial liquid product with well water available in the orchard. Trees were sprayed only once per season, one week before the first full bloom, on May 5th 2014, and April 19th 2015, with 5.3 L per tree (until full foliage wetting; total doses were 318 or 636 mg Zn tree−1 and 17 or 34 mg B tree−1). In pomegranate, flowering occurs in three waves (Holland et al., 2009), with the first one contributing most to fruit yield. Leaves were sampled from the middle part of fruiting shoots (100 leaves from the three trunks all around the canopy in each tree) on August 11th in the first season and on August 6th in the second season (approximately 90 days after full bloom). Fruits were harvested on October 22nd in the first season and on October 14th in the second season, and harvest date was based on general fruit appearance and fruit chemical properties (see below).
2.2. Plant measurements
2.2.1. Concentration of macro and micro-elements in leaves The concentrations of macro and micronutrients in pomegranate leaves were measured in the Iranian laboratory in the first season and in the Spanish laboratory in the second season. In Iran, samples were prepared as in Chapman and Pratt (1961), and total N, P, K and Ca were determined using Kjeldhal method, spectrophotometry, flame emission photometry and complexometry, respectively; B was measured using azomethine H, and Fe, Zn and Mn concentrations were measured using atomic absorption spectrophotometry (AAS). In the Spanish laboratory samples were digested using a microwave device (CarrascoGil et al., 2016) and analysed for Ca, Mg using flame emission spectroscopy, for Fe, Mn, Cu and Zn using AAS and for B using ICP-OES. Since results from the two years were similar in spite of the different methodologies used, data for the two seasons were averaged.
2.2.2. Physical properties In order to determine fruit physical properties, four fruits were selected randomly from each tree replication, and fruit weight was measured using an electronic balance. Fruit diameter, length, fruit calyx diameter (the widest part of the calyx) and peel thickness were measured using a digital Vernier gauge. In order to determine peel weight and aril percentage, fruits were manually peeled and the weight of total arils and peel were measured. The weight of 100 arils was measured and the juice volume of 100 g of arils, extracted by a manual extractor, was expressed in ml per 100 g of arils. All measurements were made according established methods (Tehranifar et al., 2010a,b; Hasani et al., 2012, 2016). For all physical parameters four replications per treatment and year were carried out.
2.2.3. Chemical properties 2.2.3.1. Titratable acidity, total soluble solids and juice pH. Titratable acidity (TA) was determined by the titration method (to pH 8.2 with 0.1 N NaOH), and results were expressed as percentage of citric acid. Total soluble solids (TSS, as%) and juice pH were measured at room temperature using a digital refractometer and a digital pH meter,

Anti-oxidant activity was etermined using 1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) (Brandilliams et al., 1995). Total anthoyanins were estimated by the pH differential method using wo buffer systems: 25 mM K chloride pH 1.0, and 0.4 M Na cetate pH 4.5 (Giusti and Wrolstad, 2001). Samples were diluted ith K chloride buffer until the absorbance of the sample at 10 nm was within the linear range of the spectrophotomeer (Cecil Bio Quest, CE 2502). The same dilution factor was ater used to dilute the sample with the Na acetate buffer. eadings were performed at 510 nm and 700 nm in the two ifferent buffers after 15 min of incubation, four times per samle. Total anthocyanin contents was calculated as follows: total nthocyanins = [(A × MW × DF × 100)/MA], where A = (A510–A700) H4.5; MW: molecular weight (449.2); DF: dilution factor; MA: olar absorptive coefficient of cyanidin-3-glucoside (26.900). esults were expressed as mg cyanidin-3-glucoside 100 g−1 of uice. Four replications per treatment and year were carried out.
Total soluble sugar contents in pomegranate juice were deterined using the anthrone reagent method (Dubois et al., 1951). certain volume of pomegranate juice was diluted with distilled ater, and then 0.1 mL of the mixture was added to four mL of
nthrone (150 mg pure anthrone in 100 mL of H2SO4 72%). The samle was heated for 10 min in boiling water at 70 ◦C, and after cooling t room temperature absorbance was determined at 625 nm using spectrophotometer. The total sugar contents was calculated using glucose standard curve. Four replications per treatment and year ere carried out.
.3. Statistical analysis
The experimental design used was a randomized complete block esign with four replications. Data were statistically evaluated by nalysis of variance (ANOVA) to assess the significance of the main actors and the significance of interactions. Combined analysis of
variance was carried out assuming environment (years and blocks) as random and treatments as fixed factors. Data were analysed using SAS (statistical analysis system; SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, U.S.A.) base 9 software, and means were compared using Duncan’s multiple range test at the p < 0.05 level.
3. Results and discussion
The leaf concentrations of Zn and B in summer in untreated trees were 13.3 and 21.1 mg kg−1 DW, respectively (Table 1). Leaf concentrations below 15 mg Zn kg−1 DW are usually found in Zn deficient trees (Benton Jones et al., 1991; Ojeda-Barrios et al., 2014), and in pomegranate trees values of 12–20 mg Zn kg−1 DW have been reported as Zn-deficient in Iran (Khorsandi et al., 2009). Regarding B, concentrations in the range 28–37 mg kg−1 DW have been found in pomegranate trees grown in controlled conditions without B in the nutrient solution (Sarafi et al., 2013, 2014), whereas in B-deficient pomegranate trees leaf B concentrations in August were in the range 28–32 mg B kg−1 DW (Korkmaz and Askin, 2015). Therefore, the Zn and B leaf concentration values found in August in the studied orchard point out to the presence of a mixed deficiency of Zn and B. On the other hand, the leaf concentrations of N, P, K, Ca and Mg were 1.84, 0.10, 0.85, 2.31 and 0.36%, respectively, whereas those of Fe, Mn and Cu were 112.0, 71.3 and 7.1 mg kg−1 DW, respectively (Table 1). These concentrations are similar to those reported in pomegranate leaves in August by Korkmaz and Askin (2015), with the exception of Mg concentrations, which were somewhat lower.
3.1. Changes in leaf mineral concentrations with foliar fertilisation
A single Zn foliar spray increased the leaf concentration of Zn, from the untreated values of 13.3 Zn kg−1 DW to 15.7–18.2 mg Zn kg−1 DW (18.0–36.8%) with the lowest dose used (0.9 mM Zn), and to 17.6–21.4 mg Zn kg−1 DW (32.3–60.9%) with the highest dose (1.8 mM Zn) (Table 1). A single B foliar spray did not increase significantly the leaf concentration of B at the lowest dose used (0.3 mM B), with B concentrations remaining at 22.3–23.0 mg kg−1 DW, whereas with the highest dose used (0.6 mM B) the final concentrations of B were 25.0–25.3 mg kg−1 DW (a 18.4–19.9% increase). On the other hand, Zn and B fertilizers, alone or combined, had not significant effects on the leaf concentrations of N, P, Ca, Fe and Mn, whereas the concentration of K increased slightly in all treatments except in Zn1 + B0 and Zn0 + B1 (Table 1).
Previous studies have shown that B and Zn sprays generally increase the B and Zn concentrations in leaves, although in many of these studies several fertiliser applications and/or higher Zn/B concentrations have been used. For instance, B sprays increased the leaf

concentration in navel orange (Maurer and Taylor, 1999), olive Perica et al., 2001) and sweet orange trees (Tariq et al., 2007), and n sprays increased the leaf concentration of Zn in pomegranate Khorsandi et al., 2009; Hasani et al., 2012) and pecan nut trees Ojeda-Barrios et al., 2014). In some cases, fertiliser applications ave been reported to cause changes in the concentrations of other utrients, possibly due to interactions in ion uptake and/or transort (Loneragan et al., 1982). For instance, in pomegranate, foliar pplications of ZnSO4 decreased the concentrations of Mn and P Hasani et al., 2012), whereas in mandarin tree leaves the applicaion of ZnSO4, either alone or combined with H3BO3, increased leaf oncentrations of Zn and K (Khan et al., 2012). In pistachio seedlings n antagonistic effect of Zn with Fe, Mn and Cu was observed, ince the concentration of Fe was significantly larger in Zn-deficient eedlings, and soil application of Zn decreased Fe concentrations by 1–13% (Shahriaripour and Tajabadipour, 2010). The lack of interctions found in our study is likely due to the low doses of Zn and
applied.
.2. Changes in fruit physical properties with fertilisation
.2.1. Tree yield, number of fruits per tree and fruit cracking Foliar spraying of Zn and B fertilizers, alone or combined,
ncreased significantly fruit yield (by 8.6-34%, depending on the reatments), with the exception of the more diluted treatments n1 + B0 and Zn0 + B1 (Table 2). Both B and Zn fertilisation seem o have an effect on yield, but with B the effect was more intense. he highest yields (18.0-18.5 kg tree−1) were obtained with the n0 + B2, Zn1 + B2 and Zn2 + B2 treatments, which led to 30.4-34.0% ncreases when compared with the control one (13.8 kg tree−1). The pplication of Zn and B led to significant increases in the number f fruits per tree (by 13.8–30.2%, depending on the treatments), xcept in the diluted treatments Zn1 + B0, Zn0 + B1 and Zn1 + B1 Table 2). Again, both B and Zn seem to have an effect on the number f fruits per tree, but with B the effect was more intense. The highst increases were found in the treatments Zn0 + B2, Zn1 + B2 and n2 + B2 treatments, which led to 24.5-30.2% increase in the numer of fruits per tree (63.0–65.9 fruits tree−1 compared with the ontrol value of 50.6 fruits tree−1). On the other hand, fruit cracking as not affected by the treatments.
Increases in fruit yield with B fertilisation have been reported in ifferent fruit crops, including almond (Nyomora et al., 1997), apple Wojcik et al., 1999), pear (Wojcik and Wojcik, 2003), persimmon Khayyat et al., 2007) and peach (Yadav et al., 2013). The combined pplication of Zn and B increased walnut yield 4-fold (Keshavarz
et al., 2011). Zinc sprays increased yield in apple (Amiri et al., 2008) and pistachio (Kizilgoz et al., 2010; Soliemanzadeh et al., 2013), and a positive correlation between Zn leaf concentration and pistachio yield (Kizilgoz et al., 2010) and a negative one between Zn leaf concentration and orange fruit drop (Garcia et al., 1984) have been reported. Increases in yield and number of fruits with Zn and B have been reported in almond (Pandit et al., 2011). Also, Zn and B fertilisation increased fruit set and the number of fruits per tree in different fruit tree species, including papaya (Jeyakumar et al., 2001), olive (Perica et al., 2001), cherry (Usenik and Stampar, 2007), palm (Sarrwy et al., 2012), and peach (Ali et al., 2014). The application of ZnSO4, either alone or accompanied with BO3H3, increased the number of fruits in mandarin trees by 17 and 21%, respectively (Khan et al., 2012). Concerning the use of nano-fertilizers, foliar sprays with ZnO nano-particles led to 26–30% increases in peanut yield when compared with ZnSO4 used at much higher doses (15- fold) in two different seasons (Prasad et al., 2012), and nano-chelate Zn has been shown to increase maize seed yield per plant almost 2-fold (Mosanna and Khalilvand, 2015).
The increased yield and number of fruits in pomegranate trees as the result of B foliar sprays are likely to be due to the known essential roles of B in fruit set, pollen grain germination and pollen tube elongation (Thompson and Batjer, 1950; Talaie et al., 2001; Wojcik and Wojcik, 2003; Baldi et al., 2004). Boron is rapidly absorbed by flowers (Sarrwy et al., 2012) and the B fertilisation effects can be attributed to its effect on fruit set and development or other metabolic processes such as carbohydrate transport, which are enhanced by its application (Peres and Reyes, 1983; Mengel and Kirkby, 2001; Marschner, 2012). The increased yield and number of fruits in pomegranate trees as the result of Zn foliar sprays are also in line with previous reports. Zinc acts in fruit bud formation and flowering (Swietlik, 1999; Usenik and Stampar, 2002), playing roles in the synthesis of tryptophan, an auxin precursor, and in the translocation of metabolites to the site of bud development or to the bud itself (Ryugo, 1988; Day, 1994).
3.2.2. Fruit size, peel thickness, arils and peel percentages, aril/peel ratio, weight of 100 arils and juice content of arils
Regarding fruit size physical parameters, fruit diameter, fruit length, fruit calyx diameter and fruit average weight were not affected significantly with the treatments when compared to the untreated controls (Table 2). However, the largest fruit diameter was obtained with the high concentrations of Zn and B (Zn2 + B2), with fruits being significantly larger (6.1–7.6%) than those obtained with the treatments Zn0 + B1 and Zn0 + B2. On the other hand, the

pplication of Zn and B did not affect significantly the aril and peel ercentages, aril/peel ratio, weight of 100 arils, juice content of arils nd peel thickness (Table 3).
In some cases, effects on fruit size have been observed with Zn nd B applications. The size of olive fruits has been reported to ncrease significantly when trees were treated by foliar applications f Zn alone or with GA3 (Ramezani and Shekafandeh, 2009), and oliar sprays of ZnSO4 and BO3H3 increased average fruit weight and uice weight percentage in mandarin (Khan et al., 2012). Increases n fruit diameter have been attributed to the role of Zn on the synhesis of tryptophan (Sahota and Arora, 1981) and auxin (Alloway, 008; Boettcher et al., 2010), therefore affecting cell elongation and ivision.
.3. Fruit chemical properties
.3.1. Juice pH, total soluble solids (TSS), titratable acidity (TA) nd maturity index (TSS/TA ratio)
Pomegranate juice pH increased significantly (by 0.28–0.62 pH nits, depending on the treatment) upon Zn and B fertilisation, xcept in the case of the more diluted treatments Zn1 + B0 and n0 + B1 (Table 4). Also, the more concentrated B and Zn treatents increased TSS in juice (4.4–7.6%), with the highest and lowest SS values (17.06 and 15.85%, respectively) being observed in trees reated by the highest concentrations of Zn and B (Zn2 + B2) and the ntreated controls, respectively (Table 4). Regarding TA, all treatents with the exception of Zn1 + B0 showed values lower than he controls (9.5–29.1% decreases, depending on the treatments), ith the lowest one being for the treatment Zn1 + B2 (Table 4). As a esult, B and Zn fertilisation markedly increased the maturity index TSS/TA ratio) (by 20.6–46.1%, depending on the treatment), due o the increases in TSS and decreases in TA (Table 4). The highest ncrease in the maturity index was obtained in the trees sprayed
ith the treatment Zn2 + B2, followed by the treatments Zn2 + B1 nd Zn1 + B2.
Results found are in line with the increased TSS and decreased A with foliar application of ZnSO4 in pomegranate trees (Hasani t al., 2012), and with the increases in maturity index in date palm ith BO3H3 and Ca(NO3)2 applications, especially when both prodcts were applied together (Sarrwy et al., 2012). However, Zn foliar pplication has been reported to increase fruit TA in pomegranate El-Khawaga, 2007), and to have no effects on the TSS/TA ratio
hen applied alone or combination with N in sweet orange (Sahota
nd Arora, 1981). Increases in TSS in apple fruits with Zn fertilisaion have been previously attributed to Zn effects on carbohydrate ynthesis and translocation (Yogeratnam and Greenham, 1982).
3.3.2. Total phenolic compounds and antioxidant activity Results show that only the more concentrated B foliar treatments (Zn0 + B2, Zn1 + B2 and Zn2 + B2) caused small (1%) but statistically significant changes in the amount of total phenolic compounds in pomegranate juice, whereas the antioxidant activity was not affected with any of the treatments (Table 4). The highest concentration of total phenolic compounds (409.92 mg 100 g−1 fresh weight) was found with the Zn2 + B2 treatment, whereas the lowest one (406.64 mg 100 g−1 fresh weight) occurred in fruits of the control treatment.
The total phenolic compounds parameter is considered as one of the most important nutritional value parameters in pomegranate fruits (Tehranifar et al., 2010a, 2010b). Similar high phenolic compounds concentrations have been found in Iranian pomegranate varieties (300–1000 mg 100 g−1 fresh weight; Tehranifar et al., 2010b), whereas Moroccan varieties contained lower phenolic concentrations (<200 mg 100 g−1 fresh weight; Legua et al., 2012). Many investigators have observed a positive effect of Zn and B on total phenolic contents in fruits. For instance, foliar sprays of B and Zn increased total phenolic compounds in olive (Saadati et al., 2013), foliar applications of Zn and B increased the total phenolics in pungent pepper (Manas et al., 2014), and Zn foliar sprays increased phenolics contents in grape berries (Song et al., 2015). The latter authors indicate that the increase was due to an increased expression of genes responsible to phenolic compounds biosynthesis. Also, the known role of B in the metabolism of phenolic compounds (Dear and Aronoff, 1965) has been confirmed in olive trees (Liakopoulos and Karabourniotis, 2005).
3.3.3. Total sugars and anthocyanins The amount of total sugars in pomegranate fruit juice increased significantly (by 1.9–4.6%) only in the case of the combined Zn and B treatments (Zn1 + B1, Zn2 + B1, Zn1 + B2 and Zn2 + B2), whereas there was no significant effect in total anthocyanins with any of the treatments (Table 4). The highest content of total sugars (14.93 g 100 g−1 fresh weight) was obtained in trees treated with the highest concentration of Zn and B (Zn2 + B2), whereas the lowest one (14.26 g 100 g−1 fresh weight) was observed in the control untreated trees.
Increases in total sugars were found in papaya, mandarin and mango fruits after foliar applications of Zn and B (Sing et al., 2002; Babu and Yadav, 2005; Anees et al., 2011). The effect of Zn on total sugars can be due to its role in the starch and nucleic acid metabolism, and also to the activities of various enzymes involved in these biochemical reactions (Alloway, 2008), whereas the effects of B on total sugars can be ascribed to the roles of B in transport of

ugars and carbohydrate metabolism (Hansch and Mendel, 2009). hen the effect of foliar sprays of some growth regulators and minral nutrients were studied in pomegranate, it was found that Zn ecreased total anthocyanins in the first season, with the lowest alues being obtained with 0.3% Zn (Khalil and Aly, 2013).
. Conclusion
Results obtained indicate that a single foliar spray with relaively low amounts of B or Zn nano-fertilizers (34 mg B tree−1 or 36 mg Zn tree−1, respectively) led to increases in pomegranate ruit yield, mainly due to increases in the number of fruits per tree. he effect was not as large with Zn as with B, and the lowest doses f Zn and B (17 mg B tree−1 or 318 mg Zn tree−1, respectively) led o only minor effects in yield. Fertilization with the highest of the wo doses also led to significant improvements in fruit quality at arvest, including 4.4–7.6% increases in TSS, 9.5–29.1% decreases n TA, 20.6–46.1% increases in maturity index and 0.28–0.62 pH nit increases in juice pH. Physical fruit characteristics (including ruit cracking, peel thickness, fruit length, fruit calyx diameter, fruit verage weight, aril and peel percentages, the aril/peel ratio, weight f 100 arils and juice content of arils were unaffected. On the other and, changes in total sugars and total phenolic compounds were nly minor, in the ranges 1.9–4.6 and 1%, respectively, whereas the ntioxidant activity and total anthocyanins were unaffected. The pplication of Zn and B also increased the leaf concentrations of oth microelements in August, reflecting the improvements in tree utrient status.

In particular, microelements have important roles in fruit set and retention, as well as in fruit yield and quality (Singh and Ram, 1983; Khan et al., 1993).
Zinc (Zn) is one of the essential micronutrients for plants, and Zn deficiency is common in many crops (Swietlik, 1999; Marschner, 2012; Ojeda-Barrios et al., 2014).

Boron (B) deficiency is also a common micronutrient problem in agriculture, which results in yield reductions and impaired crop quality (Barker and Pilbeam, 2006).

Boron roles in plants include effects on the germination of pollen grains, the elongation of pollen tube, fruit set and yield, and is also indirectly responsible for the activation of dehydrogenase enzymes, sugar translocation, nucleic acids and plant hormones (Brady and Weil, 1996; El-Sheikh et al., 2007; Marschner, 2012).

metadata.abstractText: This study was carried out to assess the effects of the foliar application of nano-fertilizers of zinc (Zn) and boron (B) on pomegranate (Punica granatum cv. Ardestani) fruit yield and quality. A factorial experiment was conducted based on a completely randomized block design, with nine treatments and four replications per treatment. Foliar sprays of nano-Zn chelate fertiliser at three concentrations (0, 60 and 120 mg Zn L−1) and nano-B chelate fertiliser (0, 3.25 and 6.5 mg B L−1) were applied as a single spray before full bloom at a rate of 5.3 L tree−1. The application of Zn and B increased the leaf concentrations of both microelements in August, reflecting the improvements in tree nutrient status. A single foliar spray with relatively low amounts of B or Zn nano-fertilizers (34 mg B tree−1 or 636 mg Zn tree−1, respectively) led to increases in pomegranate fruit yield, and this was mainly due to increases in the number of fruits per tree. The effect was not as large with Zn as with B. Fertilization with the highest of the two doses led to significant improvements in fruit quality, including 4.4–7.6% increases in TSS, 9.5–29.1% decreases in TA, 20.6–46.1% increases in maturity index and 0.28–0.62 pH unit increases in juice pH, whereas physical fruit characteristics were unaffected. Changes in total sugars and total phenolic compounds were only minor, whereas the antioxidant activity and total anthocyanins were unaffected. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
